critique: This document establishes a cooperative framework for manpower programs, involving various federal departments and agencies, as well as state and local governments. It aims to coordinate efforts to improve employment opportunities, particularly for disadvantaged groups. The order emphasizes cooperation and planning across different levels of government. It doesn't directly address immigration, national security, or civil liberties. It leans towards government intervention in the economy by establishing manpower programs. It promotes social inclusion by targeting disadvantaged groups. It seems to balance federal and state control through cooperative planning. It doesn't significantly expand executive power, as it focuses on coordination and cooperation rather than unilateral action.
